questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to emergency following bleeding per vaginum, preceded by amenorrhea for 7 weeks. She's in hemodynamic shock with a positive serum beta hCG. On examination, a mass is palpable in the lower abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rupture ectopic pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

The above clinical scenario suggests a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Following are the features:

 

  • Positive serum beta hCG: Indicates pregnancy.
  • History of amenorrhea for 7 weeks: Clinical manifestations of ectopic pregnancy typically appear six to eight weeks after the last normal menstrual period.
  • Unstable vitals (hemodynamic shock): Suggestive of hemoperitoneum, a serious complication often seen with ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • Mass palpable in the lower abdomen: Could be due to the ectopic pregnancy or associated hemoperitoneum.

 

The classic triad of symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy are:

 

  • Pain
  • Bleeding
  • Amenorrhea

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyelonephritis: While pyelonephritis can cause abdominal pain and fever, it does not typically present with amenorrhea or positive serum beta hCG.

 

Option B. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor: This may cause abdominal pain but does not account for the positive beta hCG or amenorrhea.

 

Option C. Red degeneration of fibroid: This often occurs during pregnancy and can cause abdominal pain, but it is not typically associated with bleeding per vaginum and positive serum beta hCG in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of symptoms for ectopic pregnancy is pain, bleeding, and amenorrhea, with a positive beta hCG test and unstable vitals indicating a possible ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Page 212

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought in a drowsy state from a PHC with complaints of fever, severe lower abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge. Her friend revealed that she had had an unsafe abortion a week ago. On examination, her abdomen was distended, BP was 80/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm and RR was 36 /min. Which of the following is the most common causative agent of her present condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Escherichia coli

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario is indicative of septic abortion with endotoxic shock syndrome. Septic abortion is a serious infection of the uterus that can occur after an abortion, particularly if the abortion was performed under non-sterile conditions.

 

  • Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common organism responsible for septic abortion. It is a Gram-negative bacterium commonly found in the lower intestine of warm-blooded organisms. Its presence in the uterus can lead to severe infections, especially in cases of unsafe or incomplete abortions.

 

Septic abortion is typically characterized by:

 

  1. A rise in temperature of at least 100.4°F (38°C) for 24 hours or more.
  2. Offensive or purulent vaginal discharge.
  3. Other evidence of pelvic infection such as lower abdominal pain and tenderness.

 

The patient’s symptoms of fever, severe abdominal pain, purulent discharge, hypotension (BP 80/60 mmHg), tachycardia (PR 140 bpm), and increased respiratory rate (RR 36/min) are consistent with septic abortion and septic shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pyogenes: Although it can cause severe infections, it is not the most common organism responsible for septic abortions.

 

Option B. Clostridium perfringens: This bacterium can cause gas gangrene and other severe infections but is less commonly associated with septic abortion.

 

Option C. Clostridium sordelli: This organism can cause toxic shock syndrome associated with abortions, but it is not the most common cause of septic abortion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E. coli is the most common causative organism of septic abortion, characterized by fever, purulent vaginal discharge, and signs of systemic infection.

 

Ref: Page 194, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Compression of the inferior vena cava
Compression of the superior vena cava

questions.text: A pregnant woman has dizziness on lying down straight and this improves when she turns to one side. A possible explanation is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Compression of the inferior vena cava

 

Explanation:

 

The scenario described is characteristic of supine hypotensive syndrome, which occurs when a pregnant woman lies flat on her back, causing the gravid uterus to compress the inferior vena cava (IVC). This compression decreases venous return to the heart, leading to reduced cardiac output and subsequent hypotension and dizziness.

 

Symptoms of dizziness and hypotension improve when the woman turns to her side (Left tilt), relieving the compression on the IVC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Compression of the aorta: While the aorta can also be compressed, the primary issue in supine hypotensive syndrome is the reduced venous return due to IVC compression.

 

Option C. Compression of the superior vena cava: This is less likely to be affected by the position of the uterus during pregnancy.
 

Option D. Compression of the pulmonary vessels: This is not typically related to positional changes during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine hypotensive syndrome is caused by the compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus when a pregnant woman lies flat on her back. This condition is relieved by turning to one side, which reduces the compression and improves venous return to the heart.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of loose stools with an increase in frequency for 4 days. On examination, he is drowsy, unable to feed, and skin on pinching goes back very slowly. According to the integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness (IMNCI), this child will be classified as having: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe dehydration

 

A clinical scenario of a dehydrated child who is drowsy and not able to feed with skin going back very slowly on pinching is suggestive of severe dehydration (as per IMNCI).

 

 

Diarrhea is a condition characterized by a change in the frequency and consistency of stools, occurring more than 3 times a day. Dysentery is a type of diarrhea that is associated with the presence of blood in stools. If the condition subsides within 7 days, it is termed as acute diarrhea, whereas if it persists for more than 2 weeks, it is termed as persistent diarrhea.

 

Acute diarrhea is commonly caused by intestinal infections, with rotavirus and enterotoxigenic E. coli being the major infectious agents. Other causes of acute diarrhea include certain drugs, food allergies, and systemic infections such as urinary tract infection and otitis media.

 

Assessing the degree of dehydration is the most important aspect of evaluating diarrhea. Dehydration can occur due to excessive loss of fluids and electrolytes through diarrhea, which can lead to serious complications. Therefore, it is important to identify and manage dehydration early on to prevent complications

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child with signs of lethargy, poor feeding, and slow skin pinch return should be classified as having severe dehydration and managed urgently as per IMNCI guidelines.

questions.text: A nulliparous lady with a BMI of 23, presents with hirsutism. Ultrasonography was done and an image of the same is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polycystic ovarian syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

This ultrasound image shows polycystic morphology, often referred to as the "necklace pattern," which is characteristic of Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is a common endocrine disorder in women of reproductive age and is diagnosed using the Rotterdam criteria, where at least 2 out of the following 3 criteria must be fulfilled:

 

  1. Ultrasound morphology of PCOS: This includes ovarian volume greater than 10 ml or the presence of 12 or more follicles measuring 2 to 9 mm in diameter in one or both ovaries.
  2. Clinical or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism: This can present as hirsutism, acne, or elevated levels of androgens in the blood.
  3. Oligo or anovulation: This refers to infrequent or absent ovulation, leading to irregular menstrual cycles.

 

Given the patient's presentation with hirsutism and the ultrasound findings, PCOS is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubal block: Tubal block can be visualized by performing tests for tubal patency such as hysterosalpingography (HSG) or sono salpingography. It is typically associated with infertility but not with the ultrasound findings described here.

 

Option C. Multiple fibroids: Fibroids appear on ultrasound as hypoechoic (dark) concentric areas within the uterine wall. They do not present with the "necklace pattern" seen in the image provided.

 

Option D. Mesenteritis: Mesenteritis is an inflammation of the mesentery, the tissue that attaches the intestines to the abdominal wall. It does not present with ovarian cysts or the ultrasound findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS) is diagnosed based on the Rotterdam criteria, where at least 2 out of the following 3 criteria must be present: polycystic ovarian morphology, clinical or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism, and oligo or anovulation.

 

Ref: Williams Gynecology 3rd edition pg 387

choices.text: Administer IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

questions.text: A one-and-a-half year old child is brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, fever <37 degrees, cough, and cold. On examination, the respiratory rate was 46/min, and there were no chest retractions. Which is the most appropriate management? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home


The clinical scenario described here is consistent with a diagnosis of pneumonia, but it is not classified as severe pneumonia or very severe disease based on the given symptoms. The child has a respiratory rate of 46/min, which, while elevated, does not show signs of severe distress (e.g., chest indrawing or general danger signs) that would necessitate immediate hospitalization or IV antibiotics.

 

In cases of pneumonia without severe symptoms, the appropriate management includes administering an oral antibiotic for 5 days, advising the mother on how to soothe the child’s throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy, and warning about danger signs that would require immediate medical attention. The child should also have a follow-up in 2 days to ensure that the condition is improving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer IV antibiotics and observe: This option would be appropriate for severe pneumonia or very severe disease, where the child shows signs of severe distress (e.g., chest indrawing, general danger signs). In this case, the child’s symptoms do not warrant such aggressive management.

 

Option B. Administer IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre: This management step would be necessary for very severe cases of pneumonia where immediate advanced care is needed. However, the child in this scenario does not meet the criteria for such a referral.

 

Option D. Administer only home remedies: While soothing remedies are recommended, relying solely on home remedies without antibiotics would not be appropriate for a case of pneumonia. Oral antibiotics are necessary to treat the infection.

 

Educational Objective:


For a child with pneumonia but without severe symptoms, the appropriate management includes administering oral antibiotics, advising on home care, and scheduling a follow-up to monitor progress.

questions.text: Which part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in genital tuberculosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ampulla

 

The ampulla is the most common part of the fallopian tube to be involved in genital tuberculosis. Genital tuberculosis frequently affects the fallopian tubes, and the involvement is usually bilateral. The spread of the disease is typically hematogenous from a primary infective focus in the lungs.

 

In genital tuberculosis:

 

  • The ampulla is affected in 55% of cases.
  • The isthmus is involved in 25% of cases.
  • The infundibulum is affected in 18% of cases.
  • The interstitial part is least affected, with only 2% involvement.

 

The ampulla's susceptibility may be due to its anatomical and physiological properties, making it a common site for infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infundibulum: Involved in 18% of genital tuberculosis cases, making it less commonly affected compared to the ampulla.

 

Option C. Isthmus: This part of the fallopian tube is involved in 25% of genital tuberculosis cases, which is also less common than the ampulla.

 

Option D. Interstitium: This part is the least affected by genital tuberculosis, with only 2% involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ampulla is the most commonly involved part of the fallopian tube in genital tuberculosis, with a prevalence of 55%.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition page 207, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition pg 162

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth, is found to be cyanosed with irregular gasping respiration. Heart rate is 60 beats/min, and a grimace is seen with some flexion of extremities. The Apgar score for this newborn is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

 

In this baby:

 

  • Color, blue - score 0
  • Heart rate, <100 beats/min - score 1
  • Grimace- score 1
  • Some flexion of the extremities - score 1
  • Irregular respiration - score 1

 

Thus the total score is 4.

 

Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the baby is responding to resuscitative efforts.

 

A total score of 10 indicates that the infant is in the best possible condition. An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An Apgar score is calculated based on five criteria, each ranging from 0 to 2. A score of 0-3 indicates severe distress, 4-6 indicates moderate difficulty, and 7-10 indicates that the newborn is in good health. The described baby, with a total score of 4, requires close monitoring and possibly further medical intervention.

questions.text: The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Senile endometrial atrophy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Senile endometrial atrophy is the most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding. It occurs due to the thinning and atrophy of the endometrial lining, which can lead to spontaneous bleeding.
  • Other potential causes of post-menopausal bleeding include:
    • Endometrial cancer
    • Endometrial polyp
    • Endometrial hyperplasia
    • Exogenous estrogens from hormone replacement therapy or other sources.
  • It is crucial to rule out malignancy in cases of post-menopausal bleeding by performing endometrial sampling. This procedure can also be done on an outpatient basis using a Pipelle (endometrial sampler).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervical cancer: Although a significant concern, it is not the most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding.

 

Option C. Endometrial cancer: While an important cause, it is less common than senile endometrial atrophy.

 

Option D. Hormone replacement therapy: Can cause bleeding but is less common than senile endometrial atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is senile endometrial atrophy.

 

Ref: D.C Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology page 559

questions.text: A pediatric surgeon is planning the optimal timing for cleft palate surgery on a young patient. For the repair of the soft palate, at what age should the surgery ideally be performed? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 months

 

Soft palate repair is typically performed between 3 to 6 months of age. This early intervention is crucial as it facilitates better outcomes in terms of speech development and minimizes the risks associated with feeding difficulties. Early repair allows for more normal development of speech patterns as the child grows, which is vital for effective communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The timing of cleft palate surgery –

 

  • For the soft palate, surgery is ideally conducted at 3 -6 months
  • For the hard palate repair is done at 12-15 months.

questions.text: Cannon ball metastases on chest X-ray are seen in? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Choriocarcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Cannonball metastases refer to multiple, round, well-circumscribed nodules seen on a chest X-ray, typically representing metastatic deposits. These are characteristic of hematogenous spread to the lungs.

 

 

Choriocarcinoma:

 

Choriocarcinoma is a highly malignant trophoblastic tumor that often follows a molar pregnancy but can also arise after a normal pregnancy or abortion.

 

It is known for its aggressive nature and tendency to metastasize early, particularly to the lungs, where it can cause cannonball metastases.

 

Despite its aggressive nature, choriocarcinoma responds well to chemotherapy, and lung metastases are associated with a relatively good prognosis compared to other metastatic sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complete mole: This refers to a hydatidiform mole, a type of gestational trophoblastic disease, which may precede choriocarcinoma but does not directly present with cannonball metastases.

 

Option C. Invasive mole: This is a type of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia that invades the myometrium but typically does not present with cannonball metastases in the lungs.

 

Option D. Partial mole: This is a type of molar pregnancy with less malignant potential than a complete mole and does not present with cannonball metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cannonball metastases on a chest X-ray are a hallmark of choriocarcinoma, representing lung metastases that, despite indicating spread, are associated with a good prognosis due to the tumor's sensitivity to chemotherapy.

questions.text: Rachitic rosary is seen with which deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Rachitic rosary is a classic finding in rickets, a condition caused by Vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D is essential for calcium absorption and bone mineralization, and its deficiency leads to impaired bone growth and mineralization, resulting in features like rachitic rosary. The prominence of the costochondral junctions, referred to as rachitic rosary, is due to impaired bone mineralization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Rachitic rosary is not associated with Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A deficiency primarily leads to impaired vision (night blindness), dry skin, and immune system issues.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy, primarily manifests with symptoms such as bleeding gums, petechiae, and impaired wound healing. Rachitic rosary is not associated with Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency primarily leads to bleeding disorders due to impaired blood clotting, but it is not associated with rachitic rosary. Vitamin K deficiency does not affect bone mineralization in the same way as Vitamin D deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rachitic rosary is a classic finding in rickets, a condition caused by Vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text:
The normal placenta is: (FMGE JUNE 2022)

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Discoid
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Hemochorial
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Deciduate
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3

 

Explanation:

 

The human placenta is characterized by the following features:

 

  • Discoid: The placenta has a disk-like shape, which is typical in humans.
  • Hemochorial: This term indicates that the chorion (the outer fetal membrane) comes in direct contact with maternal blood. The majority of the placenta is derived from vessels.
  • Deciduate: This means that the placenta is shed or expelled during parturition (childbirth).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discoid: While it is true that the placenta is discoid, this option alone does not cover all characteristics of the normal placenta.

 

Option B. Hemochorial: Although the placenta is hemochorial, this option alone is incomplete.

 

Option C. Deciduate: The placenta is deciduate, but this option alone is insufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The human placenta is discoid in shape, hemochorial in nature, and deciduate, meaning it is shed at parturition.

 

Ref: D C Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page 32

choices.text: Bath the baby with warm water immediately

questions.text: A mother delivers a 2.5 kg baby with normal vaginal delivery in a rural area. Which of the following is an incorrect statement? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bath the baby with warm water immediately

     

Newborn care practices emphasize immediate and appropriate actions to ensure the health and safety of the infant. Bathing the baby immediately after birth is discouraged because the baby's skin needs to adapt to the new environment, and the vernix (a protective layer on the skin) should be allowed to remain on the skin for as long as possible to provide a barrier against infection. Immediate bathing can lead to hypothermia and is generally not recommended, especially in settings where environmental conditions (such as warmth and cleanliness) are not optimal.

 

The recommended practice is to wait at least 24 hours and then start with gentle sponging until the umbilical cord falls off, typically within the first week of life. Only after this can full baths be introduced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exclusive breastfeeding: This is the recommended feeding method for newborns, providing optimal nutrition and immunity support. It should be started within the first hour of birth.

 

Option C. Clean the eyes: Cleaning the eyes is a standard neonatal practice to prevent infection. This is part of routine newborn care and helps prevent neonatal conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Skin to skin contact: Skin-to-skin contact is encouraged immediately after birth as it helps regulate the newborn's body temperature, promotes bonding, and supports breastfeeding initiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is not recommended; it should be delayed until the umbilical cord falls off, and gentle sponging should be started after 24 hours to maintain hygiene and prevent hypothermia.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and amenorrhea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and signs of ascites are positive. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Genital tuberculosis

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of genital tuberculosis. The following features support this diagnosis:

 

  • Amenorrhea: Genital tuberculosis can affect the menstrual cycle, often leading to amenorrhea.
  • Palpable abdominopelvic mass:BIn genital tuberculosis, the mass is typically a tubo-ovarian mass that is adherent to the omentum and adjacent structures.
  • Fever, weight loss, and abdominal pain: These are classic systemic symptoms of tuberculosis.
  • Ascites: The presence of ascites can be associated with advanced cases of genital tuberculosis.
  • Low-grade fever: The presence of a classic low-grade fever helps to differentiate genital tuberculosis from other conditions listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Submucous fibroid: Submucous fibroids are benign tumors of the uterus that can cause abnormal uterine bleeding and pelvic pressure but are not typically associated with systemic symptoms like fever and weight loss.

 

Option B. Ovarian malignancy: Ovarian malignancy can present with a pelvic mass and ascites but is less likely to be associated with low-grade fever and the classic history of tuberculosis symptoms.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: Ectopic pregnancy typically presents with acute abdominal pain and bleeding, not with chronic symptoms like weight loss and low-grade fever. Additionally, the presence of ascites is unusual in ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genital tuberculosis should be suspected in patients with a history of amenorrhea, systemic symptoms such as low-grade fever, weight loss, and abdominal pain, along with a palpable abdominopelvic mass and ascites.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Page 137

choices.text: Breast cancer in the opposite breast

questions.text: A patient with unilateral breast cancer is started on tamoxifen. This will increase the risk of: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrial cancer

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is used in the treatment and prevention of breast cancer. While it acts as an anti-estrogen on breast tissue, it has a partial estrogen agonist effect on the endometrium. This effect increases the risk of endometrial cancer by 1-2%.

 

Women on tamoxifen therapy are advised to undergo regular transvaginal ultrasounds (TVS) to monitor for endometrial thickening, which can be an early sign of endometrial hyperplasia or cancer.

 

Risk factors for endometrial cancer include:

 

  • Obesity
  • Use of unopposed estrogen
  • Tamoxifen use
  • Prior family history or personal history of endometrial cancer
  • Endometrial hyperplasia
  • Uterine fibroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovarian cancer: Tamoxifen use does not increase the risk of ovarian cancer.

 

Option C. Breast cancer in the opposite breast: Tamoxifen is actually used to reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence and the development of new breast cancers.

 

Option D. Cervical cancer: Tamoxifen does not increase the risk of cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen therapy in breast cancer patients increases the risk of endometrial cancer. Regular monitoring with transvaginal ultrasound is recommended to detect early signs of endometrial pathology.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Page 355

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is brought to OPD with complaints of cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. Blood investigations reveal total leucocyte count to be >50,000 cells/L. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azithromycin

 

Neonate with complaints of paroxysm of cough followed by apnea and leucocytosis (>50,000 cells/ L) points to diagnosis of pertussis, for which DOC is Macrolides, i.e., Azithromycin.

 

Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

 

A well appearing young child begins to choke, gasp and flail the extremities with face reddened. Apnea and cyanosis may follow the coughing.

 

 

Infants < 3 months do not display the classic stages of whooping cough. Catarrhal phase is usually unnoticed.

 

Treatment – Macrolides

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin: This antibiotic is not effective against Bordetella pertussis and is not used for the treatment of pertussis.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: This antibiotic is an alternative treatment for pertussis in patients who cannot tolerate macrolides but is not the first-line therapy.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: This antibiotic is not typically used for the treatment of pertussis and is not considered the first-line treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infants presenting with pertussis (whooping cough), characterized by paroxysmal cough and elevated leukocyte count, the drug of choice is azithromycin.

questions.text: The highest incidence of ureteric injury is seen in? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wertheim's hysterectomy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ureteric injury is most commonly associated with Wertheim hysterectomy than other hysterectomies due to the radical nature of the procedure.
  • But the most common cause of ureteric injury is still ABDOMINAL hysterectomy as this is the most commonly done type of hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic hysterectomies are also associated with a high incidence of ureteric injuries (After radical hysterectomyP
  • Overall incidence of ureteric injury is 0.5 -1 percent of all pelvic operations.

 

Wertheim’s hysterectomy: As mentioned is a radical surgery involving extensive dissection and hence the chance of injury is most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. Abdominal hysterectomy: Ureteric injury may occur during complex cases with distortion of anatomy such cervical fibroids, broad ligament fibroids, endometriosis etc

 

Option A. Vaginal hysterectomy: Ureter may also be injured in a vaginal hysterectomy although rare.

 

Option D. Emergency Caesarean section: It is a rare complication (1 in 1000) and occur in cases while trying to control bleeding when there is a lateral extension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureteric injury is most commonly associated with Wertheim's hysterectomy due to its radical nature, involving extensive dissection around the ureters.

 

Ref: D. C Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition page 425

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a woman with atrophic vaginitis with complaints of itching? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Topical estrogen

 

Explanation

 

Topical estrogen:

 

  • Atrophic vaginitis, also known as vaginal atrophy, is a condition that commonly affects postmenopausal women due to decreased estrogen levels. It leads to symptoms such as vaginal dryness, itching, and discomfort.
  • Local estrogen preparations are preferred over systemic hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for the treatment of postmenopausal vaginal atrophy. This is because local treatments directly target the affected area and have fewer systemic side effects.
  • The use of 1 g of conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally, applied each day for 1 to 2 weeks, generally provides symptomatic relief for women experiencing atrophic vaginitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroids: Steroids are not the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis. They do not address the underlying cause, which is the lack of estrogen.

 

Option C. Antihistamines only: Antihistamines may provide temporary relief from itching but do not treat the underlying cause of atrophic vaginitis, which is estrogen deficiency.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as topical estrogen is the recommended treatment for atrophic vaginitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis, particularly in postmenopausal women, is the application of topical estrogen to provide symptomatic relief and address the underlying estrogen deficiency.

 

Ref: Page 1469, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecology

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image below: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Placenta previa

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows placenta previa.

 

The grades of placenta previa are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Type I (Low-lying): A major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the internal os.
  • ﻿﻿Type II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it. This can be anterior or posterior
  • ﻿﻿Type III (Incomplete or partial central: The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • ﻿﻿Type IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vasa previa: Blood vessels traversing through membranes overlying the internal os in front of the presenting part may be present in a velamentous placenta. Bleeding occurring due to rupture of membranes in such a case is of fetal origin.

 

Option C. Placenta accreta: It is a form of adherent placenta where placenta is directly adherent to myometrium.

 

Option D. Abruptio placenta: It refers to premature separation of a normally situated placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted in the lower segment of the uterus, partially or completely covering the cervix, which can lead to complications such as bleeding during pregnancy and delivery.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition page 284

questions.text: What is the most common cause of seizures in a 2-year-old child? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Febrile seizures


Febrile seizures are the most common cause of seizures in children aged 6 months to 5 years, particularly in those around 2 years old. They are defined by the following criteria:

 

  • They occur in association with a fever, specifically at a body temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher.
  • They are not caused by central nervous system infections, such as meningitis, or by metabolic imbalances.
  • They occur in the absence of a prior history of afebrile seizures (seizures without fever).

 

The initial management of febrile seizures includes the administration of benzodiazepines such as lorazepam, midazolam, or diazepam to stop the seizure. Hydration and the use of antipyretics to control fever are also essential components of treatment. In cases where febrile seizures last longer than five minutes, rectal diazepam is recommended as a rescue medication that can be administered at home.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Trauma to the head: While head trauma can cause seizures, it is not the most common cause in a 2-year-old child. Trauma-related seizures would typically be associated with a recent injury or noticeable neurological symptoms, which are not indicated in this scenario.

 

Option B. Malnutrition: Malnutrition can lead to seizures due to electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypoglycemia or hypocalcemia, but it is not the most common cause in a child of this age. Febrile seizures are more prevalent.

 

Option D. Neurological deficit: Seizures can result from underlying neurological conditions, but these are less common compared to febrile seizures in a healthy child of this age group.

 

Educational Objective:


Febrile seizures are the most common cause of seizures in children between 6 months and 5 years of age, particularly around the age of 2 years.

questions.text: Cogwheel sign on ultrasound is seen in? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrosalpinx

 

The cogwheel sign on ultrasound is a classic appearance seen in hydrosalpinx, which is a condition characterized by the dilation of the fallopian tube filled with serous fluid. This appearance occurs due to the presence of longitudinal folds within the dilated tube, giving a cogwheel-like projection visible on a cross-sectional ultrasound image. The cogwheel sign is highly suggestive of a chronic hydrosalpinx and helps differentiate it from other adnexal pathologies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian cancer: Ovarian cancer can present with a variety of ultrasound findings, such as complex cystic structures or solid masses, but the cogwheel sign is not associated with ovarian cancer.

 

Option C. Endometriosis: Endometriosis may appear on ultrasound as ovarian endometriomas, commonly called "chocolate cysts," which have a homogenous ground-glass appearance. The cogwheel sign is not typical of endometriosis.

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts, or mature cystic teratomas, have characteristic appearances such as echogenic nodules, calcifications, and sometimes the "tip of the iceberg" sign on ultrasound. The cogwheel sign does not pertain to dermoid cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cogwheel sign on ultrasound is a key diagnostic feature of hydrosalpinx, representing the cross-sectional view of a dilated fallopian tube with internal folds.

choices.text: Elemental calcium of 1200mg/ day is recommended
Oral vit D3 is to be given with calcium
Teriparatide is to be started first if treatment with teriparatide and bisphosphonates is being considered
Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year

questions.text: A 60-year post-menopausal obese lady presents with backache. She has a history of Colle’s fracture 1 year back. A DEXA scan shows a T score of less than - 2.5. Which of the following is false? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year

 

Explanation:

 

Management of Osteoporosis:

 

  • Elemental Calcium and Vitamin D:
    • Postmenopausal women are recommended to take 1200 mg/day of elemental calcium along with 400-800 IU of vitamin D to help maintain bone health and reduce the risk of fractures.
  • Bisphosphonates:
    • Bisphosphonates such as Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate, and Zoledronic acid are commonly used to treat osteoporosis. These drugs help to slow down bone resorption, thus preserving bone density.
    • The recommended duration of bisphosphonate therapy is generally 3-5 years, not limited to just 1 year. Studies have shown that longer-term use of bisphosphonates can continue to provide benefits in reducing the risk of fractures. However, the exact duration should be individualized based on the patient's risk factors and response to treatment.
  • Teriparatide:
    • Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone that stimulates new bone formation. It is particularly beneficial in patients with severe osteoporosis or those who have not responded well to bisphosphonates.
    • When considering treatment with both teriparatide and bisphosphonates, it is often recommended to start with teriparatide first to build bone and then follow with bisphosphonates to maintain the bone density gains achieved with teriparatide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elemental calcium of 1200mg/day is recommended: This statement is true. Adequate calcium intake is essential for bone health, especially in postmenopausal women.

 

Option B. Oral vit D3 is to be given with calcium: This statement is true. Vitamin D3 helps in the absorption of calcium and is recommended to be given along with calcium supplements.

 

Option C. Teriparatide is to be started first if treatment with teriparatide and bisphosphonates is being considered: This statement is true. Starting with teriparatide helps build bone density, and following with bisphosphonates helps maintain the gains.

 

Option D. Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year: This statement is false. Bisphosphonates can be given for a longer duration, typically 3-5 years, depending on the patient's individual risk factors and response to therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisphosphonates are typically recommended for a duration of 3-5 years in the treatment of osteoporosis, not limited to just 1 year.

 

Ref: Page no 500, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: What is the use of the instrument given below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysterosalpingography

 

  • The above image shows Leech-Wilkinson cannula which is used for injecting dye in hysterosalpingography.
  • It is inserted into the cervix. The grooved edges fit into the cervix and allow for easy installation of the dye without extravasation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myomectomy: It is removal of fibroids. May be performed laparoscopically Or by laparotomy based on size, number, location of fibroids

 

Option C. Endometrial biopsy: It is useful for patients with AUB. It can be performed by EB curette or endometrial sampling using pipelle may be used.

 

Option D. Conization of cervix: It can be performed using cold knife or laser. It refers to excision of the ectocervix and a small portion of the endocervical canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Leech-Wilkinson cannula is used for injecting dye during hysterosalpingography to investigate the shape and patency of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg 38

questions.text: The maternal part of the placenta is called as? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decidua basalis

 

 

Explanation:

 

The decidua basalis is the specific part of the decidua (the endometrium of the pregnant uterus) that directly interacts with the chorion frondosum (the fetal part of the placenta) to form the maternal part of the placenta.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decidua parietalis: The remaining part of the decidua lining the uterine cavity that is not involved in the formation of the placenta.

 

Option B. Decidua capsularis: The part of the decidua that covers the embryo and the gestational sac, like a capsule.

 

Option D. Decidua spongiosum: This term is not typically used to describe parts of the decidua in the context of placentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Decidua basalis: Forms the maternal part of the placenta.
  • Decidua capsularis: Encloses the rest of the gestational sac.
  • Decidua parietalis: Lines the remainder of the uterus.

questions.text: Scorbutic rosary is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin C

 

Scorbutic rosary is a clinical sign of scurvy, a condition caused by Vitamin C deficiency. Scorbutic rosary refers to the swelling of the costochondral junctions due to impaired collagen synthesis, which occurs in scurvy. Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen, and its deficiency leads to weakened blood vessels, poor wound healing, and characteristic skeletal abnormalities such as scorbutic rosary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Scorbutic rosary is not associated with Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A deficiency primarily manifests as impaired vision (night blindness), dry skin, and immune system issues.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to rickets, which can cause rachitic rosary, but not scorbutic rosary. Scorbutic rosary is specifically associated with Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy).

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency primarily leads to bleeding disorders due to impaired blood clotting, not scorbutic rosary. Scorbutic rosary is not associated with Vitamin K deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scorbutic rosary is a clinical sign of scurvy, a condition caused by Vitamin C deficiency.

questions.text: What is the average duration of lochia discharge in a puerperal woman? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24-36 days

 

Explanation:

 

The average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman is about 24-36 days. Lochia is the vaginal discharge that occurs for the first few weeks during the puerperium, the period following childbirth when the mother's body, including hormone levels and uterus size, returns to a non-pregnant state. The discharge originates from the uterine body, cervix, and vagina and is a mix of blood, mucus, and uterine tissue.

 

Lochia has a peculiar offensive fishy smell and an alkaline reaction that tends to become acidic towards the end of the discharge period. Depending on the color variation of the discharge, it is categorized as follows:

 

  • Lochia rubra (red): Occurs during the first 1-4 days postpartum and is primarily composed of blood, making it bright red in color.
  • Lochia serosa: Occurs from days 5-9 postpartum, with the color transitioning to yellowish, pink, or pale brownish due to the decreasing amount of blood and increasing mucus and leukocytes.
  • Lochia alba (pale white): Occurs from days 10-15 postpartum and consists mainly of white blood cells, mucus, and epithelial cells, giving it a pale white appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-15 days: This duration is shorter than the average period of lochial discharge, which generally extends beyond 15 days.

 

Option B. 10-20 days: This duration is also shorter than the typical 24-36 days for lochial discharge.

 

Option D. 36-42 days: While some women may experience lochial discharge for this duration, it is longer than the average duration of 24-36 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The average duration of lochia discharge in a puerperal woman is about 24-36 days.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Page170

questions.text: Which among the following options describes the chest X-ray image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coeur en sabot

 

Chest X-ray image describes "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

 

  • "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot ("Coeur-en sabot").
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Egg on side appearance: Egg on string appearance is seen in transposition of great arteries (TGA)

 

Option C. Egg on string appearance: Scimitar sign is seen in Scimitar syndrome which is also known as partial anomalous pulmonary venous return.

 

Option D. Snowman sign: Snowman sign is seen in supracardiac TAPVC

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), which results from right ventricular hypertrophy, leading to the distinctive cardiac silhouette.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with primary infertility is found to have bilateral tubal block on HSG. The next best step is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopy with chromotubation

 

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is often the first test used to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes in women experiencing infertility. If the HSG reveals a bilateral tubal block, the next best step is to confirm the findings through laparoscopy with chromotubation. This procedure allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs and the fallopian tubes. Chromotubation involves the injection of a dye through the fallopian tubes to assess their patency directly, which is more accurate than imaging alone. Additionally, if the block is confirmed, there may be an opportunity to address it surgically during the same procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IVF: While IVF is a valid treatment option for tubal factor infertility, it is generally considered after confirming the tubal block with laparoscopy. IVF is often chosen if re-canalization attempts fail or if the patient prefers to bypass surgery.

 

Option C. IUI (Intrauterine Insemination): IUI is not suitable in cases of confirmed bilateral tubal block because it requires at least one patent fallopian tube for sperm to reach the egg.

 

Option D. Letrozole: Letrozole is an ovulation induction agent used in women with ovulatory dysfunction. It is not appropriate for treating tubal block issues and thus is not relevant in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After identifying a bilateral tubal block on HSG in a woman with primary infertility, the next best step is to confirm the diagnosis with laparoscopy and chromotubation before considering other treatments like IVF.

questions.text: IUCD having the longest life span is: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CuT 380 A

 

Explanation:

 

  • CuT 380 A has the longest life span.
  • It is named CuT 380 A because the surface area of copper is 380 mm.
  • Its higher surface area is responsible for its greater efficacy.
  • CuT 380 A maybe replaced after 10 years

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progestasert: It is a progesterone (38 mg) containing IUD, which is no longer manufactured. It had a shorter lifespan.

 

Option C. Mirena: It is a LNG containing IUD (52 mg LNG released at the rate of 20 mg per day). It is replaced every 7 years.

 

Option D. Nova T: It is similar to Copper containing IUD but additionally it has a silver core.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The CuT 380 A intrauterine contraceptive device has the longest life span, which can be used for up to 10 years.

 

Ref: D. C Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th Edition page 480, Williams textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg 109

questions.text: Most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PDA

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS).

 

 

Heart disease in congenital rubella: PDA > PS > VSD > ASD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ASD: ASD is the common congenital heart disease in down syndrome

 

Option B. VSD: VSD is the common congenital heart disease in infant of diabetic mother

 

Option D. PS: PS (pulmonary stenosis) is the common congenital heart disease in noonan and Alagille syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), followed by Pulmonary Stenosis (PS).

questions.text: What is the best-recommended management in a case of vault prolapse with cystocele and rectocele? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A & B

 

Explanation:

 

Vault prolapse, which involves the descent of the vaginal vault (the apex of the vagina) often accompanied by cystocele (prolapse of the bladder into the vagina) and rectocele (prolapse of the rectum into the vagina), requires a comprehensive surgical approach to repair both the anterior and posterior vaginal walls.

 

  • Anterior colporrhaphy involves the repair of the anterior vaginal wall to correct the cystocele.
  • Posterior colpoperineorrhaphy involves the repair of the posterior vaginal wall and perineum to correct the rectocele.

 

This dual approach effectively addresses both components of the prolapse, providing better anatomical and functional outcomes.

 

Other treatment options for vault prolapse:

 

  • Site-specific repairs: Involves both anterior and posterior colporrhaphy.
  • Sacrospinous fixation: Suturing the vaginal vault to the sacrospinous ligament to provide support.
  • Abdominal or laparoscopic sacro-colpopexy: Considered the gold standard for vault prolapse, this involves attaching the vaginal vault to the sacrum using a mesh.
  • Colpocleisis (Le Fort repair): A procedure that closes off the vaginal canal and is usually reserved for women who are no longer sexually active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior colporrhaphy only: This would address the cystocele but not the rectocele.

 

Option B. Posterior colpoperineorrhaphy only: This would address the rectocele but not the cystocele.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: While a hysterectomy removes the uterus, it does not address the prolapse of the vaginal vault, cystocele, or rectocele. Additional repairs are still necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of vault prolapse with cystocele and rectocele typically involves both anterior colporrhaphy and posterior colpoperineorrhaphy to effectively repair both the anterior and posterior vaginal walls.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Page 211

choices.text: Casal necklace – vitamin B3 deficiency
Vitamin D deficiency
P. alba (Pityriasis alba)

questions.text: Identify the image and it is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Casal necklace – vitamin B3 deficiency

 

Casal necklace is a dermatological manifestation observed in pellagra, which is caused by Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency. It presents as a symmetrical rash around the neck region. Pellagra is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. The dermatitis often appears in sun-exposed areas, resulting in the distinctive Casal necklace.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to rickets, a condition characterized by soft, weak bones and skeletal deformities such as bowed legs and widened wrists. The image described does not depict these skeletal changes.

 

Option C. Rickets: Rickets is associated with Vitamin D deficiency and presents with skeletal abnormalities like bowed legs, widened wrists, and delayed growth. The image does not show these features, ruling out rickets as the correct diagnosis.

 

Option D. P. alba (Pityriasis alba): P. alba, also known as pityriasis alba, is a skin condition characterized by small, raised, white or flesh-colored bumps on the skin, typically affecting children. It is not associated with a specific vitamin deficiency but rather with blocked sweat ducts. The image described in the question is not consistent with pityriasis alba.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Casal necklace is a classic dermatological manifestation of pellagra, which is caused by Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency.

questions.text: Match the following:(INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

The correct matching of the procedures with their respective characteristics is as follows:

 

  • Amniocentesis (A-4): This procedure involves the assessment of amniotic fluid, often for detecting alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and other genetic conditions. It is generally performed between 15-18 weeks but may be done later as well.
  • Chorionic Villous Sampling (B-1): CVS is performed earlier in pregnancy, typically between 10-13 weeks. It involves sampling of placental tissue to test for chromosomal abnormalities and genetic conditions.
  • Fetal Blood Sampling (C-2): Also known as cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), this procedure is done around 19-20 weeks to obtain fetal blood, often for testing fetal anemia, infections, or genetic conditions.
  • Fetoscopy (D-3): This procedure involves visualizing the fetus directly in utero and is used in specific circumstances to assess fetal anatomy and perform interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1: Incorrect because Chorionic Villous Sampling (CVS) is not done at 19-20 weeks, and fetoscopy does not typically involve amniotic fluid assessment.

 

Option B. A-2, B-3, C-1, D-4: Incorrect because Amniocentesis is not done at 19-20 weeks, and fetal blood sampling is not done at 8-12 weeks.

 

Option D. A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1: Incorrect because Amniocentesis is not used to visualize fetal organs, and Chorionic Villous Sampling is not done at 19-20 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the appropriate timing and purpose of various prenatal diagnostic procedures such as Amniocentesis, Chorionic Villous Sampling, Fetal Blood Sampling, and Fetoscopy.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 882, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 741

questions.text: A laborer’s younger child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor


The clinical presentation described in this scenario is typical of Kwashiorkor, a form of acute severe malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema, apathy, and specific changes in appearance. Kwashiorkor commonly affects infants and young children, particularly between the time of weaning and the age of 5 years. The hallmark features of Kwashiorkor include:

 

  • Edema: The presence of generalized edema, which often begins in the feet and lower legs, and eventually spreads to other parts of the body, including the abdomen, leading to the characteristic swollen belly.
  • Facial appearance: Children with Kwashiorkor often have a "moon face" appearance, with facial edema and a dull expression.
  • Hepatomegaly: The enlarged abdomen can also be due to liver enlargement (hepatomegaly) with fatty infiltration.
  • Skin changes: The child may present with skin lesions known as "flaky paint dermatosis," characterized by dark, peeling, cracked patches with pale skin underneath.
  • Hair changes: The hair becomes fine, thin, and brittle, and can be easily pulled out. There may be color changes in the hair, known as the "flag sign," where bands of depigmented (lighter) hair alternate with normal-colored hair.
  • Diet: The history of being primarily fed rice water, which lacks adequate protein, is a common contributing factor to the development of Kwashiorkor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marasmus: Marasmus is another form of severe malnutrition, but it is caused by a deficiency of both calories and protein. Children with Marasmus typically appear very thin with a "baggy pants" appearance due to the loss of subcutaneous fat and muscle wasting. Unlike Kwashiorkor, there is no edema or swollen belly in Marasmus.

 

Option C. Indian childhood cirrhosis: This condition is related to chronic liver disease and is not associated with the acute severe malnutrition signs like edema and "moon face." It also presents with different clinical features such as jaundice and hepatomegaly, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is characterized by fever, irritability, conjunctivitis, strawberry tongue, and edema of the hands and feet. It does not present with the swollen belly or the nutritional deficiencies described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:


Kwashiorkor is a form of severe malnutrition characterized by edema, a swollen belly, apathy, and specific skin and hair changes due to a deficiency of protein in the diet.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman complaints of inability to conceive, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic pain. She has a history of frequent pelvic inflammatory disease. Hysterosalpingogram shows an absence of peritoneal spillage on the right side. Identify the given clinical scenario: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tubal block

 

  • The above clinical scenario is of a tubal block
  • Tubal block commonly happens secondary to
    • PID - Salpingitis (Chlamydia)
    • Genital tuberculosis
    • Adhesions due to previous surgery
    • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa
  • If tubal block on HSG; next best step is Hysteroscopy-Laparoscopy
  • Treatment of proximal tubal block: hysteroscopic cannulation OR IVF
  • Treatment of distal tubal block: Fimbriectomy OR IVF

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometriosis: Endometriosis refers to the presence of endometrial tissue at locations other than uterine cavity. It typically presents with dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia, and infertility. This option is ruled out because of the HSG findings and presence of PID in the above question.

 

Option C. Asherman syndrome: It refers to the formation of intrauterine adhesions (synechiae) and presents with hypomenorrhea, amenorrhoea and infertility. It occurs following genital TB, PID or due scarring caused by repeated curettage. It may appear as a distorted or obliterated cavity with adhesions upon imaging.

 

Option D. Bilateral hydrosalpinx: It occurs following genital infections such as Tuberculosis and PID. Imaging shows dilated distended fluid filled fallopian tubes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tubal block commonly occurs secondary to PID, genital tuberculosis, adhesions due to previous surgery, and salpingitis isthmica nodosa. The absence of peritoneal spillage on HSG indicates a tubal block, and the next best step is hysteroscopy-laparoscopy.

 

Ref: D.C Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology page247, Williams textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg441

questions.text: Which of the following can reduce the risk of endometrial cancer in a post-menopausal woman on hormone replacement therapy (HRT)? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adding progesterone to Estrogen

 

Explanation:

 

  • Adding progesterone to estrogen in HRT can reduce the risk of potential endometrial cancer.
  • For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur with continued estrogen therapy.
  • For women without a uterus just estrogen therapy is sufficient.
  • Hormone therapy is only indicated for the treatment of osteoporosis, vasomotor symptoms, and vaginal atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Combined oral contraceptive pills: These may be used for women with premature menopause or premature ovarian failure but are not specifically for reducing the risk of endometrial cancer in post-menopausal women on HRT.

 

Option B. Clonidine: It is an alpha-adrenergic agonist used to treat post-menopausal hot flushes when estrogen is contraindicated, such as with hypertension, but does not reduce the risk of endometrial cancer.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: It may be useful in treating genitourinary symptoms but does not have a role in reducing the risk of endometrial cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adding progesterone to estrogen in hormone replacement therapy reduces the risk of endometrial cancer in post-menopausal women with an intact uterus.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Page: 62,63

questions.text: Identify the image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibroid


The image shows a well-circumscribed, whitish lesion within the uterine cavity, which is characteristic of a submucosal fibroid. Fibroids, also known as leiomyomas, are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus. They can present as distinct, well-defined lesions that are separate from the normal myometrial tissue, often appearing white or light in color compared to the surrounding pink myometrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Adenomyosis:  is incorrect because adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium, leading to a uniformly enlarged and diffusely thickened uterus without distinct, well-defined lesions.

 

Option C. Endometrial polyp:  is incorrect as polyps are usually small, soft, and protruding growths that arise from the endometrial lining. They do not appear as a well-defined, firm, and large mass like the fibroid shown.

 

Option D. Endometrial cancer: is incorrect because endometrial cancer typically presents as irregular, vascular, and possibly friable growths within the uterine cavity, not as a smooth, well-defined mass.

 

Educational Objective:


Fibroids are well-defined, circumscribed lesions within the uterine cavity that are distinct in color and structure compared to surrounding myometrial tissue, distinguishing them from other uterine conditions like adenomyosis, polyps, and cancer.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with complaints of mass per vaginum, as shown in the below image was posted for operative repair. During the pre-anesthetic check-up, she was found to be unfit for major surgery. Which of the following procedures is recommended for her? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Le Fort's repair

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given scenario suggests uterine prolapse in an elderly woman found to be unfit for major surgery.
  • Le Fort's repair is recommended in this case. It is a colpocleisis procedure that involves obliterating the vagina.
  • Indications for Le Fort's repair include:
    1. Patients who do not wish to retain sexual function.
    2. Very elderly menopausal patients with advanced prolapse.
    3. Patients medically unfit for major surgeries.
  • This procedure can be performed under regional anesthesia.
  • During Le Fort's repair, vaginal flaps from the anterior and posterior vaginal walls are excised, and the raw areas are opposed in the midline with sutures, preventing the uterus from prolapsing.
  • Before colpocleisis, a pap smear and endometrial biopsy are necessary, as once the vagina is obliterated, access to the cervix or endometrium will no longer be possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal wall Cervicopexy: Purandare's sling used strips of rectus sheath and fixed them to the anterior surface of the uterus. This was later modified using a Mersilene tape fixed to the anterior uterine surface.

 

Option B. Shirodkar's sling procedure: This procedure involves the fixation of tape to the posterior uterine surface, with the ends fixed to the sacrum. It is surgically complicated and increases the risk of sigmoid injury.

 

Option D. Khanna's sling procedure: This procedure involves the fixation of the ends of the tape to the anterior superior iliac spines.

Sling surgeries may be useful in patients with nulliparous prolapse or congenital uterine descent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Le Fort's repair, a colpocleisis procedure, is recommended for very elderly menopausal patients with advanced uterine prolapse who are medically unfit for major surgeries.

 

Ref: D C Dutta’s textbook of Gynaecology 3rd edition pg 221

choices.text: Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia and infertility. A diagnosis of endometriosis was made, and she was posted for laparoscopy surgery. During the procedure, dense pelvic adhesions were seen with the bowel stuck to the fundus and cystic ovaries stuck to each other. What is the next step in managing this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystectomy and adhesiolysis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario describes a case of endometriosis, characterized by severe dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. During the laparoscopic surgery, the presence of dense pelvic adhesions and cystic ovaries suggests advanced endometriosis. The optimal management for this condition involves:

 

  • Cystectomy: Surgical removal of the cysts (endometriomas) from the ovaries.
  • Adhesiolysis: Surgical removal of the adhesions to restore the normal anatomy and improve fertility.

 

For patients with endometriosis, especially those desiring future fertility, surgical management to remove endometriomas and adhesions is the preferred approach. This can help alleviate pain and improve fertility outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LUNA for chronic pelvic pain (Laparoscopic Uterine Nerve Ablation): This procedure involves cutting the nerves to the uterus to reduce chronic pelvic pain. However, it has not been found effective in treating chronic pain associated with endometriosis.

 

Option B. Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge: This medication has antiprogesterone, antiestrogenic, and androgenic properties. It may help in reducing symptoms by decreasing the LH surge but is not a definitive treatment for severe cases with extensive adhesions and endometriomas.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy and oophorectomy: This is a definitive treatment for endometriosis in women who do not desire future fertility. It involves the removal of the uterus and ovaries, thus eliminating the source of endometriosis. However, it is not suitable for a young woman desiring future fertility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe endometriosis with dense pelvic adhesions and cystic ovaries, the preferred surgical management involves cystectomy and adhesiolysis to alleviate symptoms and improve fertility.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg 243

choices.text: A secondary oocyte arrested in Meiosis 1
A primary oocyte arrested in Meiosis 1
A primary oocyte arrested in Meiosis 2
A secondary oocyte arrested in Meiosis 2

questions.text: In oogenesis, after ovulation, the egg is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A secondary oocyte arrested in Meiosis 2

 

Oogenesis is the process by which the female gametes, or ova, are produced. This process begins in fetal life, where the primary oocytes are formed and arrested in the diplotene phase of Meiosis 1. These primary oocytes remain arrested until puberty, at which point they complete Meiosis 1 to form a secondary oocyte and a polar body, both of which are haploid.

 

After ovulation, the secondary oocyte enters Meiosis 2 but does not complete it; instead, it becomes arrested in Metaphase 2. This secondary oocyte remains arrested until fertilization. If fertilization occurs, Meiosis 2 is completed, resulting in the formation of a mature ovum. If fertilization does not occur, the secondary oocyte remains arrested in Meiosis 2 and is eventually discarded.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A secondary oocyte arrested in Meiosis 1: This is incorrect because the secondary oocyte arrests in Meiosis 2, not Meiosis 1. The arrest in Meiosis 1 applies to the primary oocyte during fetal development until puberty.

 

Option B. A primary oocyte arrested in Meiosis 1: This is incorrect because the primary oocyte is arrested in Meiosis 1 until puberty, not after ovulation.

 

Option C. A primary oocyte arrested in Meiosis 2: This is incorrect because the primary oocyte does not enter Meiosis 2. Only the secondary oocyte enters and arrests in Meiosis 2.

 

Educational Objective:


After ovulation, the egg is a secondary oocyte that is arrested in Meiosis 2 and will only complete this division if fertilization occurs.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in a 55-year-old woman who presents with post-menopausal bleed? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrial biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

The investigation of choice for a 55-year-old woman presenting with post-menopausal bleeding is an endometrial biopsy. Post-menopausal bleeding can be a symptom of endometrial cancer, hyperplasia, or other abnormalities of the endometrial lining. An endometrial biopsy allows for direct sampling and histopathological examination of the endometrial tissue, which can help identify the underlying cause of the bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pap smear: A Pap smear is primarily used for cervical cancer screening. It is not suitable for evaluating post-menopausal bleeding, as it does not provide information about the endometrium.

 

Option C. Fractional curettage: Fractional curettage involves scraping the endometrial lining and the cervical canal. It can be used if the endometrial biopsy is inconclusive or if there is a strong suspicion of cancer. However, it is more invasive compared to an endometrial biopsy.

 

Option D. CA-125 estimation: CA-125 is a tumor marker that may be elevated in ovarian cancer and other conditions. It is not specific or sensitive for diagnosing endometrial cancer and is not the first-line investigation for post-menopausal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate investigation for evaluating post-menopausal bleeding is an endometrial biopsy, as it can detect abnormalities in the endometrial lining, including hyperplasia and cancer.

 

Ref: Williams gynecology 3rd edition pg 708

choices.text: Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is NOT used as a first line therapy for ADHD? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors

 

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is commonly treated with stimulant medications, which are the first line of treatment. The main drugs of choice include methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate, and dextroamphetamine. These medications work by increasing dopamine and norepinephrine levels in the brain, improving concentration and reducing impulsivity and hyperactivity.

 

Atomoxetine, although not a stimulant, is also used as a treatment option for ADHD. It works as a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and is considered a non-stimulant alternative, especially useful in patients who may not respond well to stimulants or who have contraindications.

 

Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), such as venlafaxine and duloxetine, are primarily used as antidepressants and are not typically used as first-line or preferred treatments for ADHD. These medications target different neurotransmitter systems and do not specifically address the core symptoms of ADHD as effectively as stimulants or atomoxetine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylphenidate: alpha agonist: This is incorrect because methylphenidate is a stimulant and a common first-line treatment for ADHD, although it is not an alpha agonist. It increases dopamine and norepinephrine activity in the brain.

 

Option B. Dexmethylphenidate or Dextroamphetamine: Dexmethylphenidate is a derivative of methylphenidate and is also a drug of choice for ADHD, working similarly to increase dopamine and norepinephrine levels.

 

Dextroamphetamine is a stimulant that is often used in the management of ADHD due to its efficacy in increasing dopamine and norepinephrine release, which helps in reducing ADHD symptoms.

 

Option C. Atomoxetine: antidepressant: Although it is referred to as an antidepressant, atomoxetine is actually a non-stimulant specifically approved for the treatment of ADHD, making it a valid option for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) are not the drugs of choice for ADHD, whereas stimulants like methylphenidate and dextroamphetamine, and non-stimulants like atomoxetine, are preferred treatments.

 

Remember -

 

  • Drugs used:
  • Methylphenidate: alpha agonist
  • Dx methylphenidate
  • Dextro amphetamine
  • Atomoxetine: antidepressant
  • Tricyclic antidepressants like
  • Imipramine
  • Clonidine, guanfacine

choices.text: Complete mole is triploid, partial mole is diploid
GTDs include complete mole, partial mole, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma and placental site trophoblastic tumor
Multi-agent chemotherapy is indicated in low-risk choriocarcinoma
Lung metastases indicate a high-risk tumor

questions.text: Which is correct regarding gestational trophoblastic disease? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GTDs include complete mole, partial mole, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, and placental site trophoblastic tumor

 

Explanation:

 

GTDs include complete mole, partial mole, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, and placental site trophoblastic tumor: This is correct. Gestational trophoblastic diseases (GTDs) encompass a range of disorders originating from the trophoblastic tissue, including complete mole, partial mole, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, and placental site trophoblastic tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete mole is triploid, partial mole is diploid: This statement is incorrect. A complete mole is diploid (46XX or 46XY), typically arising from fertilization of an egg with no genetic material by one or two sperm. A partial mole is usually triploid (69XXX, 69XXY, or 69XYY), resulting from fertilization of a normal egg by two sperm or by one sperm that duplicates its chromosomes.

 

Option C. Multi-agent chemotherapy is indicated in low-risk choriocarcinoma: This statement is incorrect. Low-risk choriocarcinoma is typically treated with single-agent chemotherapy, such as methotrexate. Multi-agent chemotherapy is reserved for high-risk cases.

 

Option D. Lung metastases indicate a high-risk tumor: This statement is incorrect. While lung metastases indicate metastasis, in the context of gestational trophoblastic disease, they often respond well to treatment and are considered low risk when the disease is confined to the lungs and shows good prognosis with methotrexate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational trophoblastic diseases include a variety of trophoblastic tumors and conditions, and the treatment and prognosis vary depending on the specific type and risk factors associated with each condition.

choices.text: 24 hours - 12 weeks after delivery
Shortly after the delivery of placenta

questions.text: When does secondary post-partum hemorrhage develop? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24 hours - 12 weeks after delivery

 

Explanation:

 

  • Secondary postpartum hemorrhage occurs between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery.
  • Primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) occurs within 24 hours of childbirth with the most common cause being atonic PPH.
  • Causes of secondary PPH include:
    • Retained placenta
    • Endometritis
    • Placental polyp
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • AV malformations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Within 6 hours of delivery: This falls within the timeframe of primary PPH, not secondary.

 

Option B. Within 24 hours of delivery: This also describes the period for primary PPH.

 

Option D. Shortly after the delivery of placenta: This timing is also associated with primary PPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary postpartum hemorrhage develops between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Page 483, 484

questions.text: MgSO₄ toxicity: all are monitored except? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Routine serum Mg level


Magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) is commonly used in obstetrics to prevent seizures in preeclampsia. Monitoring for toxicity is crucial, and the primary clinical parameters to monitor include respiratory rate (RR), urine output, and deep tendon reflexes (DTR). A decrease in these parameters can indicate magnesium toxicity. Routine measurement of serum magnesium levels is not standard practice unless clinical signs of toxicity are present or there is concern based on monitored parameters. Serum levels are checked only if there is clinical suspicion of toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RR (Respiratory Rate): Monitoring respiratory rate is critical because respiratory depression is one of the first signs of magnesium toxicity. A rate below 12 breaths per minute can indicate toxicity and necessitates intervention.

 

Option B. Urine output: Urine output is monitored because reduced kidney function can lead to magnesium accumulation and toxicity. An output of less than 30 mL/hour suggests the need for caution and potential dose adjustment.

 

Option C. DTR (Deep Tendon Reflexes): DTRs are closely monitored as they are among the first clinical signs to diminish with rising magnesium levels. Loss of reflexes indicates that magnesium levels are dangerously high.

 

Educational Objective:


Routine serum magnesium levels are not typically monitored during magnesium sulfate therapy unless clinical signs of toxicity are present.

questions.text: Which vaccine is typically stored in the lowest compartment of the ILR? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) OPV

 

In an Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR), vaccines are stored at specific temperatures to maintain their potency. The lowest compartment of the ILR is the coldest part, which is optimal for storing vaccines that require the coldest temperatures. Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) is stored in the lowest compartment because it requires the coldest storage conditions to remain effective.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penta: Pentavalent vaccine (which protects against five diseases: diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, hepatitis B, and Haemophilus influenzae type b) does not require the lowest temperature and is generally stored in the middle compartments.

 

Option B. DPT: The DPT vaccine (Diphtheria, Pertussis, and Tetanus) does not need to be stored in the coldest compartment and is kept in the upper or middle compartments of the ILR.

 

Option C. Hep B: The Hepatitis B vaccine also does not require the lowest storage temperature and is kept in the middle compartments of the ILR.
